ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: My singing has improved greatly with Janna! Having consistent lessons is a game-changer.
I built a stronger familiarity and comfort in my singing voice in a shockingly short amount of time. Great connection to fabulous people in the School of Music!
playing oboe
great one on one voice training
Continuing piano interpretation.
I was able to further my private study of the violin.
I furthered my percussion performance abilities.
Techniques for practicing Bach - chords and intonation now phrasing in Bruch, and Sarasate
I improved my technical skills on the bassoon and developed my overall musicality.
I feel I greatly improved my technical and musical skills over this past semester. I feel I physically have more control over my hands and body, and am a more confident player.
I really didn't enjoy my classes. I felt like I didn't learn much and the things I did "learn" I disagreed with.
I was able to vastly improve my vocal technique and increase my repertoire of arias and lieder.
Learning how to listen closely and correctly to make adjustments to make better music!
I continued my studies in violin performance and believe that Wendy Sharp is an excellent teacher to facilitate growth.
Lots of new approaches to cello playing-- I love Ole!
Developed my vocal and acting ability a lot. Learned a lot of repertoire.
I learned classical vocal technique and elements of performance.
My technique and hand strength have improved a lot.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course is a bit taboo in that it's essentially just weekly voice lessons. That said, the course is directed and aimed at improving what you are looking to improve upon. In that vein it behaves more so as a guided independent study. Loved the formatting.
they're lessons
The communication about the lessons program in general could be improved - it's been very unclear throughout what exactly the policies on required theory classes, etc. are.
Lessons are lessons; can't really be changed too much.
I sometimes felt I did not have enough time to practice, but I think this was due to the fact that I was still learning how to manage my time in my first semester.
I cannot think of any weaknesses; my lessons were always excellent!

The program itself needs to be way more organized than it was this year. I didn't even start my lessons until about halfway through September, and juries were incredibly messy as well in terms of scheduling.

Strengths: focuses on classical music technique Weaknesses: We went over very few songs and we never expanded the song choices. The teacher would choose the song for you so I hated half my songs as well.
There are no weaknesses! Taking voice lessons for credit is academically rewarding and fun.
Strength is definitely studio classmaybe wish we could have them more often?
I am very grateful that Yale offers private lessons for credit! My first semester was an incredible experience!
Strengths-- Ole is amazing. He gives lots of good advice / musical ideas. No weaknesses.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I'd recommend it to anyone looking to improve upon their skills as a classical singer. It is absolutely not aimed at pop, musical theater, or other styles of vocal performance, so do not apply if that's what you're looking for.
if you want to take lessons, you should take lessons
yes!!
Yes-- for students looking to further past studies in private instrumental studies.
If you want to keep studying your instrument at a relatively rigorous level, taking lessons is a good option.
Yes. Lessons are essential to becoming a better musician.
yep!
I would strongly recommend taking music lessons for credit because it is simply a great opportunity to get better at a musical instrument.
I would recommend this course to anyone who wants to go into performing arts, who isn't looking to spend money on first-rate voice lessons, and wants to be classically trained.
Yes! Professor Parisot is great and I feel I've learned a lot in a very friendly environment.
No
Absolutely! If you are serious about vocal technique, I would recommend taking lessons for credit.
Yes of course!
If you're interested in pursuing singing seriously, I highly recommend taking lessons for credit. They are very helpful.
I would recommend lessons to any student invested in their instrument as a soloist.
Yes, if you are a cellist you should definitely study with Ole. I always leave my lessons in awe, and feeling much better than when I came in.

I would strongly recommend voice lessons for credit. As a singer, it is so, so important to be practicing under a teacher. Bad habits form easily and leave slowly. My teacher is excellent -- we get along well, and my singing is getting better and better.
